content: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY ASSEMBLY OF THE AMERICAS. The Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas consists of not more than 13 Members of Congress who meet annually to discuss common issues in intellectual and industrial property with parliamentary groups from other countries in the Americas. A United States Delegation is appointed for each meeting to further common interests in intellectual and industrial property. The Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas consists of 13 Members of Congress appointed by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas consists of 13 Members of Congress appointed by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. In odd-numbered years starting in 1999, 7 members are appointed by the President pro tempore of the Senate based on recommendations from the Senate leaders, with specific allocations from the Committee on Foreign Relations and the Committee on the Judiciary. The Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas consists of 13 Members of Congress appointed by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The appointments are made for each meeting and include 6 members appointed by the Speaker of the House and 2 secretaries for administrative support appointed by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of each Delegation. Funding is also provided for the Assembly. The United States Delegation of the Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas receives $60,000 annually for expenses, with half approved by the Chairperson and half by the Vice Chairperson. The appropriations remain available until expended, and the Delegation must submit an annual report to Congress detailing its expenditures. The United States Delegation of the Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas receives $60,000 annually for expenses, with half approved by the Chairperson and half by the Vice Chairperson. An additional $100,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998 to cover expenses for hosting the first annual meeting. The Delegation must submit a report to Congress on expenditures, and the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson's certificate is final in auditing. The Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1961 is amended to include the Intellectual Property Assembly of the Americas in the reports of expenditures.
